By ALAN HIRSCH
English Department Chairman
Ronald Paulson has indicated
that he will leave Hopkins at the
end of the academic year for a
position at Yale University.
Paulson has not yet officially
tendered his resignation, but has
told the Dean and the President
of his decision to leave the
University. He said that a few
minor details must be worked
out before he signs a contract
with Yale.
Dr. Laurence Holland, English
Professor, has been appointed to
the deparment chairmanship. He
has been serving as department
chairman since mid-March in
order to insure a smooth transfer
of the position.
A specialist in 18th Century
literature, Paulson will in effect
supervise the Yale Center for
British Studies, which includes
the Mellon Collection, the largest
collection of 18th Century
prints, drawings, and manuscripts

in the country. Paulson's work
has centered on the relationship
of art to literature in the 18th
Century, and the art and literary
works at Yale are the subject of
much of his work.
Paulson has concentrated
particularly on the works of

Hogarth. Yale, according to
Paulson, "has the best Hogarth
collection in America."
Dean of Arts and Sciences
George Owen commented,
"Paulson is the top man in his
field, so it's only natural that he
go to Yale with the offer he has."

His decision to,go to Yale was
not based on any dissatisfaction
with Hopkins, but on what Yale
had to offer, Paulson
emphasized.
"Hopkins. has everything I
would want. It's beautiful place
in which to operate," he stated.

The panel's report represents a

semester by a joint Student

The new proposal was
described by committee

replacement of the honor
system."
Noting that the conditions
which have led to an increase in

hopes the system his panel has
proposed is sufficiently flexible

reinstituted in several years
without too much difficulty.
"It's a problem which is
affecting colleges everywhere,"
said Phillips of the increasingly
serious problem of academic
dishonesty at the undergraduate
level.
Phillips said that the panel
kept this in mind in formulating
a proposal which "would take
reasonable precautions" and still
not "impugn the integrity of
students."
The proposal touches on the
two basic problems which Honor

Commission members and
academic administrators felt
hampered the effectiveness of the
honor system—the unwillingness
of students to turn in cheaters,
and a lack of participation on the
part of the faculty in upholding
the honor code.
"We believe it is the joint'
responsibility of faculty and
students of this University to
maintain the academic integrity
of Johns Hopkins in all respects,"
the proposal reads in part. "An
ethical code must exist in the
University community to
guarantee high standards of
conduct and to limit membership
in the community to those
persons able and willing to
maintain these standards."
Under the suggested system,
students would be called upon to
make faculty members aware of
any cheating so that the
necessary precautions could be
taken. Phillips said he thinks this
will resolve a conflict which put a
damper on the effectuality of the
Honor Commission in prosecution
cheaters.
"There is a real conflict which
arises," he explained. "On the
one hand, there is loyalty to
one's peers, and on the other.
loyalty to the honor system."
"But surely," he added,"there
is no confict in simply telling a
professor that cheating is going
on.
A loose and voluntary system
such as this, Phillips feels, can
more easily revert back to an
honor system, when the time for

What everyone around here seems to know, but is
unwilling or at least hesitant to admit, is that the Union has
been one big problem from its very inception. One University
official described the difficulties being experienced with the
new building as "bugs that have to be worked out, like in any
new building."
Needless to say, the Union is infested with bugs. Costly
ones. For instance, the Glass Pavilion and the
Listening-Viewing Room can't be used at the same time. And
the noise from the Rathskellar impinges on programs in the
L-V room. Likewise for the music practice rooms,
which
cleverly enough, weren't soundproofed sufficiently. Of
the Glass Pavilion —clearly an acoustical disaster --its architect
Donald Sicklcr rcrmarkcd at the Union's dedication that it is
in need of "tuning."
Under construction, the building was the biggest headache
that plant officials have had to endure in more than a decade,
according to one Plant Operations official. And now that it's
completed, well, what can one say about a room (The Glass
Pavilion) that has to have $27 thousand dollars worth of
curtains to "tune" it. As former Dean Robert Fitzpatrick
pointed out, curtains in a room designed to constantly let as
much light in as possible makes no sense whatsoever.
After the destruction of two more shatterproof
"unbreakable" Pilkington Panes, we have proof positive that
something is drastically wrong with the construction of the
Glass Pavilion. At this point, it is time to stop marveling at
the "light and airy feeling" of the building and make it
functional. Plans to change the glass to plexiglass or protect
the glass with plastic seem like a good idea. Maybe after that,
the building can be soundproofed.
Now that the University is considering a Biology building,
it would be well for its officials to bear the lessons of the
odious Union in mind, so that the painful experiences that
have been, are, and will be, won't go for naught.

The new proposal was

replacement of the honor

Noting that the conditions

affecting colleges everywhere,"

serious problem of academic
dishonesty at the undergraduate
level.
Phillips said that the panel
kept this in mind in formulating
a proposal which "would take
reasonable precautions" and still
not "impugn the integrity of
students."

two basic problems which Honor

academic administrators felt
hampered the effectiveness of the
honor system—the unwillingness
of students to turn in cheaters,

part of the faculty in upholding

the proposal reads in part. "An
ethical code must exist in the
University community to
guarantee high standards of
conduct and to limit membership
in the community to those
persons able and willing to
maintain these standards."

taken. Phillips said he thinks this
will resolve a conflict which put a
damper on the effectuality of the
Honor Commission in prosecution
cheaters.
"There is a real conflict which
arises," he explained. "On the
one hand, there is loyalty to
one's peers, and on the other.
loyalty to the honor system."
"But surely," he added,"there
is no confict in simply telling a
professor that cheating is going
on.
A loose and voluntary system
such as this, Phillips feels, can
more easily revert back to an
honor system, when the time for
